review.title: Predictive Capacity of Meteorological Data - Will it rain tomorrow
review.abstract: With the availability of high precision digital sensors and cheap storage medium, it is not uncommon to find large amounts of data collected on almost all measurable attributes, both in nature and man-made habitats. Weather in particular has been an area of keen interest for researchers to develop more accurate and reliable prediction models. This paper presents a set of experiments which involve the use of prevalent machine learning techniques to build models to predict the day of the week given the weather data for that particular day i.e. temperature, wind, rain etc., and test their reliability across four cities in Australia {Brisbane, Adelaide, Perth, Hobart}. The results provide a comparison of accuracy of these machine learning techniques and their reliability to predict the day of the week by analysing the weather data. We then apply the models to predict weather conditions based on the available data.

metadata.title: Will it rain tomorrow?

sections.text: With the availability of high-precision digital sensors and cheap storage media, it is not uncommon to find large amounts of data on almost all measurable characteristics, both in nature and in man-made habitats. Weather, in particular, has been an area of great interest for researchers to develop more accurate and reliable forecasting models. In this paper, a series of experiments using prevailing machine learning techniques are presented to build models for predicting the day of the week, using the weather data for that particular day, i.e. temperature, wind, rain, etc., and testing its reliability in four cities in Australia (Brisbane, Adelaide, Perth, Hobart). The results provide a comparison between the accuracy of these machine learning techniques and their reliability to predict the day of the week by analysing the weather data. We then apply the models to predict weather conditions based on the available data.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Weather is perhaps the most common natural phenomenon affecting a large proportion of the human population on a daily basis. Given the large number of variables that can contribute to the overall nature of a given location, it is quite difficult to accurately predict the weather on a given day and day of the week based on the weather conditions given. In our experiments, we train our classifiers on the basis of historical data: 1. Predicting the day of the week (Mon, Tue, Wed, Thu, Fri, Sa, Sun) by analysing the given weather conditions for that day, including temperature, rain, wind and season. 2. Predicting the weather conditions for a given day, i.e. the probability of rain, wind and temperature ranges. 3. Test the robustness of these models by applying them to different cities in Australia and compare their results.

sections.heading: 2. Classifiers
sections.text: The following classification algorithms were used to create predictive models to perform the experiments: Naïve Bayes (NB) Classifier is a simple probabilistic classifier based on Bayes "theorem of strong (naïve) assumptions of independence, i.e. the classifier assumes that the presence (or absence) of a particular characteristic of a class has nothing to do with the presence (or absence) of any other characteristic, as the class variable. It is easy to build and quick to make decisions. It efficiently adapts new data by changing the associated probabilities. Random Forests (RF) Classifier is a variant of the Decision Tree Classifier. It works by building a variety of decision trees at training times and issuing the class, which is the mode of class output by individual trees. This method is similar to dredging in many ways, but the construction of each tree method differs from standard decision classification classifier.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text: The choice of discretization technique (s) and classification algorithm (s) primarily depends on the context and nature of the data available. Some algorithms are better suited to nominal values, while others perform best with numerical data. It is difficult to make a clear judgement based on the results of this experiment, but in most cases Random Forests and J48 yielded higher accuracy; slightly better results compared to IB1 and noticeably better Naïve Bayes simple. Although Naïve Bayes yielded much higher accuracy in some cases, while the others were worse. From what we observed in the test results, the accuracy of predictions decreases with increasing resolution of the results and vice versa. In other words, we can predict with greater accuracy between a smaller number of decisions (coarse resolution).
